Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Empirical, theoretical, and comparative tests of major hypotheses for the recurrent evolution of self-fertilization
Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this project is to evaluate the underlying mechanisms that drive the evolution of the ability for flowering plants to self-fertilize. This goal will be accomplished by measuring the rate at which lineages transition from outcrossing to self-fertilizing in the mustard family, a diverse and agriculturally important group. Flowering plants display an incredible breadth of variation in flower size, shape, and color that is generally attributed to the co-evolution of flowering plants and pollinators. Considering the potentially important role of cross-pollination in evolution, it is surprising that the shift to self-fertilization is one of the most common evolutionary transitions in flowering plants. Despite decades of work on this subject, it is still not clear what drives the initial spread of selfing and tests of the leading hypotheses explaining this pattern are rare. One reason for this is that a series of rapid changes in other floral traits occur in response to selfing, which then act to obscure traditional methods of comparative inference. Additionally, the project will result in the training of graduate and undergraduate students.

In flowering plants, shifts from outcrossing to selfing and from diploidy to polyploidy are common and are thought to occur in concert An association between selfing and polyploidy can occur through three non-mutually exclusive pathways. First, polyploidization could act as a filter, limiting the founding of new populations to those that originate from a self-compatible progenitor. Second, polyploidization could provide strong reproductive assurance resulting in the joint transition of mating system and ploidy. Finally, polyploidization could create a favorable environment for the spread of selfing after the population is established. This research estimates the transition rates of these three pathways in the Brassicaceae by assembling a database of mating system and ploidy data and extending a multi-state comparative model. These estimates will be used to evaluate the relative importance of reproductive assurance in the spread of selfing in neopolyploids. The model will show why simultaneous transitions to selfing and polyploidy are relatively rare in Brassicaceae and other families with sporophytic self-incompatibility (SI). The theoretical framework will be extended to explain why such SI systems can survive extreme population bottlenecks associated with polyploidy and island colonization.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merits

The major goal of this award was to develop analytical tools to better understand trait evolution. The specific intellectual merit of the research was to predict the conditions driving the evolution of self-fertilization. This is a common evolutionary trend in plants which often reduces the viability of populations. To reach this goal, the PI and co-PI developed computer programs aimed at two questions: 1) when should selfing mutations spread in self-incompatible populations?; and 2) what are the consequences of whole-genome duplication on the expression of harmful mutations?  Answers to these questions were each published in peer-reviewed articles by Evolution (see links below), and the resources have been made freely available to the public through the Dryad repository (see links below). These programs can be modified by any user to address additional questions that are relevant to organisms through evolutionary time.

1st Paper: Layman, NC, MTR Fernando, CR Herlihy and JW Busch. 2017. Costs of selfing prevent the spread of a self-compatibility mutation that causes reproductive assurance. Evolution.

Paper: https://doi.org/10.1111/evo.13167

Resources: https://datadryad.org/resource/doi:10.5061/dryad.2pj0j

2nd Paper: Layman, NC and JW Busch. 2018. Bottlenecks and inbreeding depression in autotetraploids. Evolution.

Paper: https://doi.org/10.1111/evo.13587

Resources: https://datadryad.org/resource/doi:10.5061/dryad.g81sd47

 

Broader Impacts

In addition to the intellectual merits discussed above, funding directly supported the professional development of two students. The co-PI (Layman) traveled to professional meetings and gave oral presentations on the research outcomes. These experiences improved science communication skills and simultaneously disseminated the research to a broad audience. The co-PI also trained an undergraduate to conduct related molecular biology experiments in the lab. The undergraduate student gained practical expertise in the extraction, amplification, and analysis of DNA polymorphism. In addition, the undergraduate student presented the results of the research in a poster format at the annual Evolution meetings.

These experiences trained these students to gain critical skills which led to their acquiring scientific positions (postdoc at the University of Idaho and technician at the Washington Animal Disease Diagnostic Lab, respectively) upon completion of the project.
